key_points: The House select committee issued subpoenas to the Proud Boys, the Oath Keepers, and their leaders Henry 'Enrique' Tarrio and Elmer Stewart Rhodes for the Jan. 6 Capitol riot investigation.

The committee is investigating the deadly Capitol invasion by supporters of former President Donald Trump, which temporarily halted the confirmation of President Joe Biden's Electoral College victory.
The subpoenas are part of an effort to understand how violence erupted at the Capitol and the preparations leading up to the attack.
Dozens of other subpoenas have been issued by the committee for documents and testimony related to the Jan. 6 events.
The bipartisan panel is probing the factors and events that precipitated the riot, following months of false claims by Trump that the 2020 election was rigged against him.
Prosecutors have noted coordination between Capitol riot defendants, the Proud Boys, and the Oath Keepers.
A subpoena references a "conspiracy among at least 18 Oath Keepers" to storm the Capitol with paramilitary gear and weapons.
Rhodes was indirectly mentioned in an indictment for being in direct contact with indicted Oath Keepers before, during, and after the Capitol attack.
Prior to Jan. 6, Rhodes allegedly made remarks suggesting the Oath Keepers were prepared to use violence to ensure their preferred election outcome.
The subpoenas also target 1st Amendment Praetorian, another organization involved with the events leading up to the Jan. 6 attack.
spokespersons: Bennie Thompson (D-Miss., Chairman of the Select Committee)
